Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2011 03:39PM nurse-ann wrote: 37: I replied to your original post suggesting that you get a copy of your bone scan report.  These are generally very easy to read.  I don't like the fact that your blood tests have high calcium levels.  My Onc and the Radiologist don't always agree but I like looking at all my reports because there's a physician (Radiologist) interpreting them.  That right there is a mini-second opinion.  My experience with the reports is that the radiologist is more of an alarmist (covering the butt, etc.) and my Onc is usually more of a wait and see type.  I'd get my hands on those reports. P.S.  I've just gathered almost 5 years of records together for MD Anderson.  I had a real interesting time reading all these physician notes (three Onc's) and all these tests.  For instance, the first Onc is making snide remarks in the report about me going to my Primary Care Physician for a diagnosis.  She actually found my Mets - nuts to the original Onc!
Posts.Title: This Nightmare is Getting Out of Hand - Any Help? 37antiques ebann

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2011 08:42AM - edited Jul 19, 2011 08:44AM by nurse-ann After I failed on Faslodex, I went on Xeloda and Exempra.  I had about 3 months to live at that point.  I stayed on this combo for 2 years.  The side effects can vary and sometimes are pretty wacky.  I found that I was able to stay on top of them or ahead of them and beat them into submission. One of the weirdest was an issue with my eyes.  I live in a dry climate and my eyes were so dry that the corneas of both eyes pitted and my vision blurred.  I have a very good eye doctor with a lot of chemo patients.  He sent me home with a variety of samples and I selected an ointment that did the trick.  This is what I mean about staying on top of side effects.  I have to also say that I have several doctors that I rely on - rely as little as possible on Oncologists.  It's my "other" doctors that keep me going, in my opinion.  I'm off to see my urologist tomorrow - he is always glad to see me and know that I'm still alive. Good luck to your mother on this drug.  I think its a good one.
Posts.Title: Advice needed--Xeloda Mar1065 Lynn1

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2011 09:10PM nurse-ann wrote: Good idea about the copay link.  It reduced my copay from $60 to $10.

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2011 05:39PM nurse-ann wrote: My scalp only hurt around the time my hair fell out - I've had my hair fall out three times with chemo and the "aching hair roots" are very predictable for me. When I was first diagnosed, I had a human hair wig made to look like my real hair - really well done.  I only wear it now to go out to dinner, etc.  While I'm doing yard work, I'm in my natural state.  If I make a trip to town, I usually wear a scarf - I really don't like the heat.

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2011 08:11PM - edited Jul 21, 2011 08:12PM by nurse-ann Ingrid: I was about to make a similar recommendation yesterday but was concerned that your mother may be too fragile. About 8 - 10 years ago, I had a drug resistant infection in the bone of my foot.  Ultimately, I had to have surgery but they had to get the infection under control first.  I ended up seeing an Infectious Disease Specialist.  They had me administer the drug through a line in my arm 3 or 4 times a day.  They were able to give me antibiotics that were several times stronger than what my body could absorb orally.  Good luck to you and your mother.
Posts.Title: Fighting infection for past 7 months - HELP! Ingrid78 medommer

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2011 08:58AM nurse-ann wrote: Sewingnut: I love the T-shirt - right on target.  It's a shame Koman, Avon, etc. don't sell these.  It's much closer to reality and more of the general public could use a dose of reality where BC and all cancers are concerned.
Posts.Title: Since we all love a good rant Fitztwins WingsofHope

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2011 07:43PM nurse-ann wrote: Love4MyMom: Thank you for providing the links.  I laughed for 5 minutes at the first link and have bookmarked the site.  While her terminology was funny, I don't believe that any of the other forms of cancer are subject to this offensive terminology for fund raising purposes.  The second link gave me the uncomfortable feeling that other people think they can determine what breast cancer is all about, what is offensive or not, and those of us with this disease can just deal with it or not - we are kind of irrelevant to the need that these organizations have to fund raise.  This is especially offensive since such a small amount of the money goes to Stage 4.
Posts.Title: Since we all love a good rant Fitztwins WingsofHope

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2011 03:45PM nurse-ann wrote: Just one more way to make money off of breast cancer patients!
Posts.Title: Since we all love a good rant Fitztwins WingsofHope

Posts.Content: May 1, 2011 06:05PM - edited May 1, 2011 06:07PM by nurse-ann EnglishMajor: I just read the link. Again I say, this is just another way to make money off of BC patients.  I am getting as turned off by "awareness" as I am by the term "survivor".  If you really want to scare people into being aware, tell them how many Stage 0, Stage 1 - 3 eventually end up Stage 4. "Oncology World" does not want to do this because it would scare the crap out of Stage 0, 1 ,2, 3 women and potentially impact fund raising.   In the early stages of my BC, my husband would do these Koman, Avon, ACS, functions.  One thing that I remember about these events were the luminaries (bags with lighted candles) for those that passed away.  The inference was that these men/women passed away in the "bad old days" before the advances in cancer care.  My advice to anyone into "awareness" is to get real, call NIH, and determine how many people are ever really rid of this disease.  The treatment for cancer is still, poison it, burn it, or cut it out.  Not all that much has change from the "bad old days".  How's that for those of you into "awareness".
Posts.Title: Since we all love a good rant Fitztwins WingsofHope

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2011 07:27PM - edited Apr 28, 2011 07:28PM by nurse-ann Mercifully, I am of an age that I did not know about these bracelets until I read this thread.  Maybe I've also been distracted by loosing my hair for the fourth time or maybe I was absorbed by the many creative ways I constantly employ to deal with the constant constipation from non-stop chemo. Thanks for the link to the websites above.  I really enjoyed the metastatic breast cancer site - it really tells it like it is. I'd have to say that these bracelets and the insensitivity of them remind me of the visit we got a year ago from my husbands oldest daughter.  She was so happy with her new boob job (her 40th birthday gift to herself) that she couldn't wait to show me and only remembered (after the fact) that I was a BC patient who had a mastectomy two years earlier.  As much as we'd like to believe that things have really gotten better for women (self-image, etc) it sounds like not much has improved.  How sad!
Posts.Title: Since we all love a good rant Fitztwins WingsofHope

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2011 12:45PM - edited Apr 29, 2011 12:47PM by nurse-ann If BC clothing is a fad now, let me suggest a missed marketing opportunity mentioned in an early post by lowrider54.  I refer to the "chemo treatment day bag".  This item certainly sums up my life of late and is an item that I could have gotten a lot of use out of.  It could be embossed with many of the sayings referenced on the metastatic website like "let me tell you about my side effects" or "join the fight against chronic constipation" or "what part of incurable disease don't you understand". This marketing opportunity was overlooked by allowing the drug companies to hand these out for free.  I have to admit that I graduated from one of these to my L.L. Bean carryall but think about the opportunity here for anyone into "awareness".

Posts.Title: People who disappear after diagnosis rosasmommy rosasmommy

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2011 02:53AM nurse-ann wrote: My experiences with this are too numerous to mention.  I would have to say I'm surprised by some peoples callousness and fear but also surprised by the decency of people who don't feel that way. I am the oldest of 6 - one of my sisters has never contacted me in the 4 1/2 years I've had BC - another rarely contacts me.  I have a brother and sister that occasionally touch base and a sister and mother who call daily.  Fear is a big part of this.  The worst I've seen is with other BC patients that are Stage I, II, III.  I have two friends in this category - they so much don't want to be me that I rarely hear from them unless I call them.  After my last contact with both, I've resolved to never contact them again.
Posts.Title: People who disappear after diagnosis rosasmommy rosasmommy

Posts.Content: May 1, 2011 01:06PM nurse-ann wrote: As another poster stated, there are times when the boards are not as active.  This causes your post to roll down the list and many will not see it.  I also don't reply if I do not have information to offer or my information may be dated.  For instance, my original chemos were AC and Paclitaxol.  This was 4 1/2 years ago and I barely remember the SE's, etc.  Also, I've observed periods of time when postings get very volatile elsewhere on the site and they get tons of responses and consume all the oxygen.  This could cause you to roll down the list of active topics as well. Hope you will try again in different ways.  Since I am constantly on different chemos, I find this site invaluable when it comes to getting specific info on any upcoming chemo - to use a current example I got info here that I could not get from the Onc's Nurse/Practitioner.
Posts.Title: very surprised at how unhelpful this site is amylynn1108 Moderators

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2011 05:33PM nurse-ann wrote: I think that your mother is still emotionally processing all of this.  You don't give the details regarding your mother.  If she has lobular cancer, it can be more difficult to pick up on mammo, petscan, whatever. I feel bad that she kept this to herself and may have had little support because she was trying to keep this quiet.
Posts.Title: mom's got it too now, stage IV, need feed back please mginger dianaleo

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2011 06:56PM nurse-ann wrote: Germ wise, you could wear a mask or have your mother wear one.  I don't hesitate to wear one when I feel vulnerable.  When I really had a problem eating, I would take Ensure (even though I didn't like it) or have chicken noodle soup.  At times like these, you need to treat food as a medicine that you need to keep going.
Posts.Title: mom's got it too now, stage IV, need feed back please mginger dianaleo

Posts.Content: May 11, 2011 06:43PM nurse-ann wrote: I had the "pulling away" issue when I was on Xeloda/Ixempra.  At one point, I thought I could lose 7 out of 10 finger nails.  I kept them all cut very short to not stress them or catch them on anything and was very careful with everything I did.  I would use a nail file, for instance, to open the clasp on my watch.  If I needed help with anything, I had my husband do it. I've always had long, tough nails and used them for all kinds of jobs around the house but I became very protective during this time and managed to hang on to them.  Never lost one and they are normal now.  During this time, I did not polish my nails in order to allow them to breath and not stress the nail beds. Good Luck to you.
Posts.Title: Nail Issues Due to Chemo KAM1 lago

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2009 08:42AM nurse-ann wrote: I have a regular port and I've had it for 2 and 1/2 years.  I considered having it removed and before I could do it I moved from Stage 3 to Stage 4.  The skin around the port itches but it's only a minor inconvenience.  Mine is also around 3 inches from the collarbone.  I like the idea of having it near the cleavage area - out of the way of seat belts and other irritants.  Also, go for the power port.  I've always been glad I've had my port.  My only good vein in on my mastectomy arm.  Also, the onc nurses use a numbing agent prior to accessing the port which works well.
Posts.Title: Need some input on ports...please... pee wallflower

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2009 07:45AM nurse-ann wrote: Waterlily: Thank you so much for your reply.  I attempted a PM but could not get it to work.  I would like to discuss your symptoms prior to diagnosis and your course of treatment.  I do think that ILC puts a different slant on diagnosis and testing. Again, thanks so much.
Posts.Title: Mets to abdominal cavity,kidney,urethra nurse-ann waterlily

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2011 08:19PM nurse-ann wrote: Thanks for the tip on mbcnetwork.org.  I agree that MBC needs more than it gets.  Strange since we are the only group that can "prove" the effectiveness of any of the chemos.  If you give chemo to a stage 1,2, or 3 patients after surgery, you have no way to measure effectiveness since you can't establish that they are even at risk - they have no measurable disease at that point.  You can easily do this with a stage 4 patientwith measurable disease. I feel that we are poorly served by conventional oncology.  When I ask and oncologist if they know how to take care of a stage 4 patient, some stare at me and others tell me how many of their patients are stage 4.  They seem unaware that the requirements are different and the diagnostic skill needed are much more advanced.

Posts.Content: May 10, 2011 05:36AM nurse-ann wrote: Clemson: I am encouraged by your success.  The nose bleed thing scares me a little - I'm hoping you and yaiyaicoty have good platelet levels.  I finished my 2nd round today and got a lecture from the Onc Nurse to call with any bleeding. I also live in an area with minimal humidity and I use a large humidifier in the bedroom - I think it helps.  yaiyaicoty: A trade off might be to call the chemo center tomorrow and talk to a nurse.  Also, every Oncology Center that I've gone to also has rotating oncologists.  If you call (not too late at night but maybe 7 or 8 pm, you could get good advise without a visit.  My current Onc takes emails. Before, I list my SE's I want to say that I've only done the two cycles and my dosage was reduced because of my platelets so my SE's could be milder.  I'm also getting premeds which explains why I'm hyper on chemo day emailing at 10pm. My worst SE is constipation - very bad but I try to stay ahead of it.  The day after chemo I have very bad upper GI distress and have to double up on meds for this on the day after.  I then have a couple of good days (with exception of constipation) then towards the end of the week I have a couple of days (midday) where it feels like my head is going to drop in my lap.  I have a cup of tea and just try to push through it. Six to seven days out I've had bone pain in lower back, ribs, hips, and neck but I mainly ignore this an just rub these areas and apply heat.  I don't get the Neulasta shots so my bone pain is from the chemo.  I don't consider the SE's bad with this chemo but I'm on the reduced dosage.  My onc uses the CA27-29 so I'm not familiar with the one you are doing.

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2011 03:22AM nurse-ann wrote: Hello Halaven users: I met with a nurse practitioner today regarding Halaven and I believe she gave me misinformation regarding the cycle.  From this thread and other info on the Internet, I gather that the cycle is a 21 day cycle with Halaven given on the 1st and 8th day.  I would have the third week "off".  Is that correct? Also, it seems that they do not give you premeds.  Just saline and a 5 minute injection through the line? Thanks for any information that you can provide!
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2011 05:14PM nurse-ann wrote: Thank you all for the information that only you can provide.  As you all have said, this is so new that even some of the providers can't help with all the questions.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: May 3, 2011 04:44PM nurse-ann wrote: The typical dosage is on the 1st and 8th day of a three week cycle with you having the third week off.  It's a drug that they give by pushing it into the saline line over a period of 5 minutes.  My Onc gives 2 premeds with it (one pushed and one drip).  I'm in the chair for an hour of so. Some people on the site have gotten it without premeds and some have had their timing changed due to SE's.  It's likely that they will start you on the dosage I described unless you have other problems with platelets, etc.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2011 12:59AM nurse-ann wrote: I've had this for about 6 weeks although it is fading now that I'm off this drug.  I described it to the Onc as "a stitch in my side".  The kind of thing that you can get jogging.  Mine gets better if I "hold" it for a minute.  The Onc gave me another reason for it but it might be the med after all.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2011 01:24AM - edited Jun 10, 2011 01:24AM by nurse-ann I had to even watch reaching a long way for something because that could set one off. Also, I don't get Neulasta so it couldn't be that.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2011 05:09AM nurse-ann wrote: I'm just on my second dose - getting used to the SE's with this one.  I would say that constipation is the first one.  My eyes have not been running.  I do have neuropathy that comes and goes but that may be leftover from the carbo/paclitaxol.  One thing I have noticed for 2 - 3 days after an injection is fatigue that comes out of nowhere - I feel incredibly sleepy - can't hold my head up.  I had an episode tonight around dinner and just had to go to bed for a couple of hours.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2011 05:17PM nurse-ann wrote: Marybe: In my way, I see your hair loss as a positive thing - I actually grew a lot of hair on Halaven.  The first time in 2 1/2 years, I have body hair and had to do my legs so your hair loss may be a sign that it's working. I sent an email to the Onc yesterday and I'm waiting to hear back.  I titled the email "mixed messages".  I will be at MD Anderson for a consult before seeing my Onc again - I am very concerned about the combination of spleen, platelet, and bone marrow issues with my Lobular history.  As I said previously, I was on a reduced dose of Halaven because of my platelets and there is some suspicion that these little Lobular critters could be in my bone marrow.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2011 12:17AM nurse-ann wrote: From January 2011 - April 2011 I was on carbo and paclitaxol.  Most of my minimal SE's were from the paclitaxol although the carbo didn't do my platelets any good - they were bad to start with but apparently carbo can be hard on platelets. Good Luck to you with this regimen.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2011 07:43AM nurse-ann wrote: Jeanne46: Thank you for your reply.  Am I also correct in assuming that the drug is only given on the 1st and 8th day of the 21 day cycle?  Yikes, I'm afraid to think of a drug without premeds.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: May 11, 2011 02:35AM nurse-ann wrote: Marybe: Yes, I've had 6 weeks of treatment - 2 cycles.  As others have said, sometimes it's hard to know whether or not its the premeds or the chemo.  I will talk with the Onc about increasing the dosage the next round - she is currently giving me a reduced dosage of 1.82 mg - I think the normal dose is somewhere around 2.5.  Maybe you will not have SE's - mine have been pretty constant from the start. One thing I forgot to add to my SE list is foot and leg muscle issues.  They tend to get real tight and I exercise them several times a day.  I point my toes to my shin and stretch the back of the calf - trying to keep the feet and calves limber. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2011 05:59PM nurse-ann wrote: Marybe: I was able to get relief from the foot and leg cramps in a couple of ways but had to take lasix for the edema - I only got it in the feet and legs - they felt tight as a drum. I only got the cramps at night.  I used a pillow under the knees and slept on my back and tried to avoid sudden movements.  I also tried to do little exercises during the day to stretch out the calf and leg - I point the toe of my foot up to my shin and gently stretch the calf and then flex the foot to keep it limber.  The worst cramp I had went from the back of the lower calf of the left leg right up the back of my thigh - I briefly wondered it I had a blood clot - I guess I didn't or I would know by now.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2011 07:22PM nurse-ann wrote: Marybe: My Onc and I are still debating whether or not we quit too soon.  As you may remember, my 27.29 dropped around 2300 in three weeks.  Admittedly my 27.29 was probably the highest in the world but maybe there is a delayed reaction with this drug.  Keep your chin up!
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2011 08:41PM nurse-ann wrote: Marybe: I did Xeloda for two years and feel very positive about it.  When it stopped working, I went to carboplatin/paclitaxol which never worked and she left me on it too long.  She and I went round and round over Halaven.  I thought that she was trying to experiment on me when there were many things I had not tried yet - older drugs that I thought more reliable.  I was her first Halaven patient and the University had only one other at the time.  She won the argument by stating that Halaven was very different than anything that I had tried before.  In other words, my cancer has morphed and become resistant - lets throw something completely different at it.  One thing that I did at this time was force her to come up with a treatment plan.  What would be next and how long would we give it before bailing out.  She came up with three drugs - I'm on one now.  If you get a second or third opinion, ask them for a treatment plan, too.   I'd also get a little explanation with the treatment plan.  For instance, since I bombed out on paclitaxol, she doesn't consider me a good candidate for any of the taxanes - since there are several on the "chemo list" that shortens my "chemo list" a little.  Since I've also burned my way through the hormonals, I'm down to just the "chemo list".
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: May 1, 2011 10:35AM nurse-ann wrote: I've only been on one cycle of Halaven - will start the second on Monday.  I've noticed that I can feel some effects while they are pushing it.   The following day, I feel even more.  I don't get much of a protection window from the premeds.  Also, I've done a lot of chemo but constipation is particularly bad with this one.  If I don't stay right on top of it, it upsets my entire GI tract.  Hope you feel better!
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: May 1, 2011 11:01AM nurse-ann wrote: Have you tried Miralax combined with the Senna?  I do 2 tablespoons of Miralax in orange or cranberry juice at night.  This combo works for me but I have to get the dosages right for each chemo.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: May 2, 2011 04:23AM nurse-ann wrote: ToughIrish: I have two posts above regarding the very bad constipation I've had with this drug.  It can make me feel bad from my breastbone to the top of my thighs until I get it under control.  Please watch out for that.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: May 31, 2011 08:33PM nurse-ann wrote: Just completed two cycles and had scans and TM's tested.  First, the good news.  My usually reliable TM's dropped 2203 on the 27.29 and 10.8 on the carcinoembryonic marker after 2 cycles.  However, I now have visual progression in spleen, liver, and maybe bone marrow for the first time in 2 - 2 1/2 years.  Strange mixed messages.  I have been taken off of Havalen and started Doxil yesterday.  I have to state again that I was getting Havalen at a reduced dose (1.82 mg) so I don't know how this muddied the waters.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2011 09:37AM - edited Apr 24, 2011 09:37AM by nurse-ann I'm also remembering my early days as a chemo patient and I would add that strong smells bothered me at varying times and could bring on nausea.  My husband did the cooking and he could also be a little heavy on the spices.
Posts.Title: mom's got it too now, stage IV, need feed back please mginger dianaleo

Posts.Content: May 7, 2011 02:09PM nurse-ann wrote: I worked outside during my radiation doing very physical work and had seven weeks of treatment.  I found it more tiring than the surgery and chemo - maybe it was the accumulation of all of it.  If you find yourself tired at the beginning of the last week, I would arrange for a ride home on the last 2 or 3 treatments, if you can.  Sometimes neighbors, friends, volunteers will do this for you. My butt was dragging so bad during that last appointment, I'm sure you can still see the marks in the hospital parking lot - I wished that I had anticipated this and arranged for my husband to pick me up.
Posts.Title: Working Through Radiation? Katarina pat01

Posts.Content: May 7, 2011 02:12PM - edited May 7, 2011 02:13PM by nurse-ann Also wanted to cover the skin issue.  After 7 weeks of radiation, I only had a problem on the top of my shoulder and back - that tender area that many of us have to watch when we go to the beach or hike.
Posts.Title: Working Through Radiation? Katarina pat01

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2011 03:15AM - edited Apr 19, 2011 03:17AM by nurse-ann After posting a couple of days ago, I had another thought about the piece - a sad one.  I think that some people find/stumble upon these institutions that are dedicated to treating stage 4 as a cronic disease. I first heard of this with Elizabeth Edwards diagnosis and was reminded of it in the above clip.  This approach requires very developed diagnostic skills for the Onc, a very good open relationship with the team members and patient, and the willingness to provide creative solutions with additional surgery or radiation, if needed. In other words, a team willing to do what it takes to extend life in a quality way - a team dedicated to solutions - a team that regroups when they have to.  I really envied the woman in the piece not just for her lengthened life but the quality of her support team. I have not found anything close to this in my own fight and that is sad for me and many other stage 4 patients.  I've been through 3 Onc's and I'm soon to be at MD Anderson to try to find the elusive "treatment of BC as a chronic manageable disease."  All I've essentially had for 4 1/2 years are Onc's that unimaginably work their way down the lists of hormonals and chemo's and move on to the next - a little like taking a number at the deli section - next!
Posts.Title: Local News Story Lynn1 Lynn1

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2011 08:55PM - edited Jul 16, 2011 09:01PM by nurse-ann K-Lo: I would also add that Onc's frequently withhold information.  That makes these decisions difficult.  Then we also have the great unknowns involving chemo - will the next one work for me.  If the next 3 work, I could live another 2 years, etc. I have a friend that has been battling BC for 17 years - 3 recurrences in the breast before becoming stage IV.  For most of that time her QOL was very good.  She told me several times that she would not want to live if her QOL was not good.  However, she is now so ill that she has not been able to leave the house for two years except for health related appointments.  Part of me thinks of the statement she made to me but I would not be able to have such a conversation with her. I wanted to also comment on your appointment with palliative care and your Onc's comment.  I've had three Onc's and consulted with two others.  One of my favorite questions is "Do you know how to work with a Stage IV patient?  The needs and complications are/can be very different.  When I ask this question, they look at me with a clueless look - sometimes they will recite how many stage IV patients they have - not really the same as "knowing how to care for one".
Posts.Title: Do you ever just want to stop? palaminoridesagain Bren-2007

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2011 07:43PM - edited Jul 15, 2011 07:44PM by nurse-ann There are definitely days I feel this way.  I usually snap out of it.  I find that the "medical community" bothers me more than the chemo, SE's, and reduced quality of life.  I've been through 3 Onc's and consulted with two others - the last at MD Anderson.  I do have to tell you that when my "final days" are here I wonder if I want to go through them with my current Onc.  She's very smart but I swear, I don't think she gives a crap.   My biggest fear is one you are expressing, I think.  I don't want treatment right up to the end.  I want time to myself away from the doctors, etc.  Knowing when that time is here must be one of life's toughest decisions and I hope that I have the wisdom to recognise it when I see it.
Posts.Title: Do you ever just want to stop? palaminoridesagain Bren-2007

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2011 05:42PM - edited Apr 16, 2011 05:43PM by nurse-ann It is a good but realistic story of the ups and downs of stage 4.  Since I'm trying to find something that works again (after a two year regimen that did work), this story gave me a needed shot in the arm. Thanks so much for posting it!
Posts.Title: Local News Story Lynn1 Lynn1

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2011 05:28PM nurse-ann wrote: Congrats on your good news.  This is a drug I could be on soon!
Posts.Title: It's working! mthomp2020 CoolBreeze

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2011 11:29AM nurse-ann wrote: She could have mets to the alveoli of the lungs which causes the oxygen to not diffuse properly into the bloodstream and causes low oxygen levels especially on exertion.  They would have to have a pulmonologist scope her lungs and do a biopsy.  The alveoli are air sacks at the outer edges of the lungs.  That's why I'm on oxygen 24/7.  I would also note that this happened to me before (2 1/2 years ago).  I was able to get off oxygen then as soon as the chemo started working.  Now I'm back on it.   If they suspect anything like this they would probably start with a pulmonary function test.  She could have lung function problems that have nothing to do with cancer and not show up on a scan.  As I said before, it could be associated with chemo.  My medical center has a very respected lung function lab.  Many people are treated there for COPD and other things totally unrelated to cancer.
Posts.Title: Low oxygen level curepink 2Hands4me

Posts.Content: May 5, 2011 03:45PM - edited May 5, 2011 03:48PM by nurse-ann I would try to get your second opinion from a Breast Oncologist at a University, if you can.  You may just have a bad insensitive Onc here but I would make sure that you get all your questions answered.  Go to that second opinion with a list of questions.  After that visit, you will have all your questions answered and will be armed with the information you need to make decisions.  Good Luck to you.
Posts.Title: Plse help am I stage 4? EshLou thegood5

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2011 03:01PM - edited Jun 10, 2011 03:01PM by nurse-ann I was on Ixempra for two years and did not have eye swelling per se.  I did have very bad eye problems early on to the point that my cornea's were pitted.  My eyes were so dry that my vision was blurred. I have a very good eye doctor and he has a lot of cancer patients including his father.  He sent me away with around 25 samples of drops and salves.  I settled on a salve.  It took a week or two of using it nightly and then I could use it every two or three days.  Maybe you should consider an eye doctor visit.  Note: even if you do not have coverage for eye glass and contact prescriptions, an eye doctor should consider this a medical visit.
Posts.Title: Ixempra-Side Effects maxwell677 nurse-ann

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2011 02:51AM nurse-ann wrote: Please see article from December 2010 - Bone Drug Zometa Flops in Breast Cancer Study.  Google it if you need to. The article begins by stating that "One of the most promising new approaches for fighting breast cancer took a stunning setback Thursday when a major study showed that a bone-building drug did not stop cancer from returning or extend life for most women fighting the disease". A spokesman for Novartis (the manufacturer) states that "Ten years of work and to have essentially a negative study is disappointing".  Dr. Peter Ravdin of the University of Texas states in the same article "Zometa's role in cancer prevention remains uncertain".

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2011 01:07AM nurse-ann wrote: gracem:  You did the right thing on the chemo flow sheets, I think.  I got them directly from the Onc Nurses in the chemo room.  Brace yourself for one thing though.  When you finally have your appointment, they will send you pages (via email) to fill out for the Patient Database that require dates and info from your records.  You have to show up an hour early to give them all this stuff including your CD's (in the correct format).  I just got a welcome package in the mail with all this again - just in case, I guess.  As I said before, they also email you the hotel list.  I booked the Rotary House right away. It's when they set up the appointment that they informed me about the need to get my pathology slides for reprocessing - they handle this part.  Also, I had a little give and take on the appointment so I could pick an appointment that would allow me to set up the house sitter, the dogs, the reservations, etc.  It will all work out - don't worry.

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2011 10:09AM nurse-ann wrote: MD Anderson has a self referral process now and that is how I will go there for my second opinion.  They email a checklist to you.  You must get all the information they want on the check list and get this to them.  When they have your information, they set up the appointment.  At that time they send you a hotel list and New Patient Questionnaires.  I must have my CD's and the Questionnaire at the hospital one hour before my appointment - 7 AM on July 11th.  I was assigned a coordinator and I faxed all the required records to her.  As soon as she had my records and the appointment was set, she ordered my pathology slides - they will be sent to Anderson to be redone.

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2011 01:48AM - edited Jul 18, 2011 01:50AM by nurse-ann This surgeon made her decision on her reasonable fear of the unknown and the "yet to be discovered".  She did not want to gamble her life only to find that some development would totally invalidate common practice or "scientific method". When I was diagnosed, my treatment followed the current standard which they now question.  As I said in my prior post, we do the best we can with the information that we have.  I would also have to say that about twice a day, the Stage IV group welcomes 2 new members.  Many of these women were Stage 0, 1, or 2 at diagnosis.  Some were under the "impression" that they were "cancer free" for 10, 15, or even 21 years.  An Onc or BS is very aware of what can happen and how often it happens and did not want to risk that.

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2011 12:41PM nurse-ann wrote: The first two years I had BC, I did not feel the need for anti-anxiety meds or an anti-depressant.  I would say that this was a time for me when I mostly lived in the moment and "one day at a time".  Following that, I was hospitalized for 8 days and nearly died.  I was so shaken by this, I began (and continue) to take a small dose of Ativan at night. If I wake up at night, I go right back to sleep without ruminating or worrying.  After this near death experience, I found that for the first time, I was overcome by grief and fear and began to see a psychologist who works with cancer patients.  He had me on a low dose of Celexa for around 6 months. I only see the psychologist "as needed" but this has helped me a lot.  He has been a great resource and this allows me to have discussions that I would not want to have with my husband and especially my mother or other family members.

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2011 01:01AM - edited Jun 19, 2011 01:05AM by nurse-ann GraceM:  I'm a little ahead of you.  I collected all the records from 3 cancer clinics and all the scans - about 4 inches of paper.  They won't do the appointment until you get all this info to them.  I then found that I would have to wait about 3 months for an appointment.  A member here emailed her doctor and after reviewing my file, he decided to see me and short cut the process.  We are also coming a long way by motor home since I am on oxygen 24/7. My appointment is at 7 am on July 11th. I also understand the need to coordinate your current treatment.  When you say this to them, they suggest that you interrupt treatment but I can't right now.  I'm very fortunate (if that's the right word) to be on a "once a month" chemo which made the logistics possible. Also, they want you to plan to be there for 1 1/2 weeks.  They also informed me (after the appointment was made) that they would order my pathology slides from my former pathologist and redo the pathology.  They informed me that the insurance may or may not cover this - I'm letting you know this now so you can plan.  Personally, I'm only planning to be there for a week and will be staying at the Rotary House the night before the appointment - this hotel is next to the Cancer Center on University Property as I understand it. For the remainder of the week, we will be 12 miles away at an RV Resort. We do have the ability to extend our trip, if we need to but that would be more difficult for someone with air and hotel reservations. My advise to you is get through the paper gathering process ASAP.  I fax everything I collect as I collect it.  Also, keep in touch with your contact person frequently.
Posts.Title: thinking of heading to MD Anderson for consultaton gracem PJB

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2011 12:16AM - edited Jul 19, 2011 12:55AM by nurse-ann Yes, but you are basing your comment on "what is currently known and currently disseminated".  All that could go out the window in two years.  The difference between what you are saying and what others have posted is that not all of us believe this stuff.  If that seems harsh to Oncology, consider my earlier remarks.  When I was diagnosed, it was common to give AC and Paclitaxol to women with high estrogen/progesterone - I was stage III then.  Now (5 years later) they realize that this in not effective and women like me would have been better off by going on AI's immediately. Chemo for high estrogen is not effective even the dose dense chemo that I had.  Oh well, it's just my life - who cares but me. It would not have mattered what Onc or hospital I went to 5 years ago - this was common practice. Also, after re-reading your post, you seem to put a lot of trust in mammograms.  I had one every year and ended up with a large tumor and heavy node involvement.  These tests (Pet Scans, mammo's, CT Scans are not effective for many people but that's a whole different story.  If you are up for some really scarry reading, go to the Stage IV forum and find out how many women went from Stage 0, 1, 2, 3 under the care of Oncologists.  Both mother and daughter in this article would like to avoid this although it may be too late for mom.

Posts.Title: Need Help fiaa Lillian

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2011 04:13PM - edited Jun 7, 2011 04:15PM by nurse-ann "Studies" are fine but when did we start experimenting on humans without their consent.  I was on this drug at my expense for two years.  I resent doing R&D for companies that should be doing their own.  The article that I mentioned calls for Novartis to go through trials to substantiate their "claims".  As a stage IV patient, I have enough experimentation on my body with these damn cancer drugs that are rushed through FDA approval and then later taken back from the market - we saw one late last year and two more that I expect to occur this year. Let me also point out a drug company trick called off-label prescribing.  Novartis got FDA approval for this drug for osteoporosis at two dosages per year.  Once they got FDA approval, they began to pedal this to Onc's for BC, Prostate, Lung Cancer, etc. Not only does this substantially broaden their market from a few old ladies with osteoporosis, they up the dosage to once a month. Yes, I'm angry about the two years that my insurance company paid for this drug - but I'm one of the lucky ones that does not have a cap on my insurance.  Some cancer patients are dealing with 350,000, 500,000, or 1 million dollar caps on their insurance - when the money's gone it's gone.  If Novartis wants to experiment on humans, let them advertise in the paper for volunteers, pay those volunteers in addition to free drugs, go through clinical trials and get FDA approval for this drug as a cancer preventative.  Let them do their own G. D. R&D - these drug companies make gobs of money off cancer patients.
Posts.Title: New Article/Info on Zometa Pure Latte

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2011 11:25PM - edited Jul 5, 2011 11:27PM by nurse-ann Wow!  I think that there's denial then there's denial.  I have various degrees of it in my family.  It's too hard for my 85 year old mother to contemplate loosing a child, for instance.  My husband is usually 6 - 12 months behind where I am on the reality curve but he has some grip on reality and knows where this is all heading.  My sister is a nurse and I can talk to her but sometimes the reality is too much for her and she has to take breaks from it.  I think that you are facing a difficult problem with your family because of the sustained coping mechanisms they have for denial that have been forged over a life time.  I wish you luck with this.  I wonder if a pastor or councilor would have ideas for you so you could begin to wade through your families old coping mechanisms with them and get them to see life as it really is.

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2011 05:29AM nurse-ann wrote: I don't know if this will help or not.  I'm on my third Onc and this one is very competent but not very forthcoming.  She wants to make all the decisions and have me trust her but after what I went through with the first two "that ain't happening". To make a long story short, she and I are doing a better job of sizing each other up and finally building a relationship after 6 months.  But let me tell you what I do - I pickup the scans from the organization that does them (last 5 years worth) and I hand carry them to her office.  The CD's come with a very descriptive typed report from the radiologist.  I read them, highlight them, and use them as the basis for my questions. I also graph all my blood work and can trend my platelets, TM's, liver function, you name it. What you also have to ask yourself is "do you want this much information".  I have to admit that I take a deep breath before reading these radiology reports.  The benefit of reading these reports is that you do have two medical doctors giving opinions about what they see. My Onc sometimes disagrees with the radiologist or takes a more conservative view but at least I have two opinions. Good Luck to you and keep us posted.

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2011 06:20AM nurse-ann wrote: I would also add that most doctors don't like to say things that might upset a patient.  That would go double if they are still assessing the situation.  I would also not conclude that you have a poor prognosis.  People respond in wildly different ways to the same treatments. With my first Onc, I got up the nerve and ask him if I was now Stage IV and that my cancer had metastasised.  His eyes teared up and he said "Yes".  He would not have used those words with me if I had not forced the issue.

Posts.Content: May 9, 2011 10:39AM nurse-ann wrote: In my case, I actually graph my bloodwork and try to be on top of everything.  This approach could be very stressful for another individual.  My psychologist treats a lot of cancer patients and earlier in his career he really pushed his patients to be major advocates for their treatments - be aggressive.  After a time, he found that he was stressing some people out and learned to promote advocacy for those so inclined.  Your mother may also be a person that doesn't like to push or ask the next "natural" question that is begging to be ask.  My mother (a healthy 85 year old) is very hard to get any information out of - she simply never asks the right questions.  It took me a while to learn where my nephew was attending law school.  Although, she talks to him frequently, she never bothered to ask!

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2011 08:19PM nurse-ann wrote: wrgjc: I have mets to the peritoneum and the first visible symptom was ascites.  I was very ill at the time and hospitalized for 8 days.  I had exploratory surgery and a new pathology report while hospitalized.  The pathology report confirmed the mets and also changes to my estrogen/progesterone levels - no more hormonal treatments after that - they would not work.  The ascites (yellowish clear fluid) drained quite a bit as a result of this surgery.  The best way to deal with it is a chemo that works.  I went on Exempra and Xeloda when I left the hospital and stayed on it for two years. No more ascites.  When I go for abdominal CT scans, what they look for first is the return of ascites.

Posts.Content: May 9, 2011 10:01AM nurse-ann wrote: I agree with the above posts - it does seem over the top to not tell you but I also agree that many of these doctors won't give you information unless you specifically ask.  When I became stage 4, my first onc never used the word "metastatic" or "stage 4" in the discussion.  I said "does this mean I'm stage 4" and his eyes teared up.  Be very direct with your questions, if your mother can handle this.  She might have her limits with this kind of directness - I don't but some cancer patients do. I believe that one reason cancer patients are so keen on running around telling everyone that they are "cancer free" is that they need to misinterpret what the doctor is saying to them and the doctors don't correct them.  That's a whole other discussion that I ended up having with the same Onc referenced above.
Posts.Title: Mis information? Hello12 Chickadee

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2009 04:52PM nurse-ann wrote: I found radiation more tiring than chemo and I worked full time through both.  It may have been because I had rad's for 7 weeks every day during the summer - a real grind.  I had minor fatigue for around 6 months after.  When I say minor, I went to work every day but was in bed every night by 8pm.  After 6 months, my energy was normal again.  I would also add that I feel more positive about the effectiveness of radiation than I do chemo even with the fatigue.
Posts.Title: side effects of radiation therapy Maria217 Imasurvivor

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2009 10:03PM nurse-ann wrote: I have scheduled an appointment at the University of Colorado's Dept of Breast Cancer Oncology a couple of months from now.  They are doing a lot of research there.  In addition to getting a second opinion from an onc that only works with bc patients, I want to find out what is on the horizon research wise.
Posts.Title: side effects of radiation therapy Maria217 Imasurvivor

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2011 04:23PM - edited Jun 6, 2011 04:35PM by nurse-ann I have confirmed mets to peritoneum and pelvic floor muscle (exploratory surgery confirmed this), suspected mets to avioli in the lungs and possible mets to bone marrow.   I'm on oxygen 24/7. I had many PET scans with my first Onc and they never showed cancer even the day I was admitted to the hospital and almost died.  He kept waiting for the PET to show something and I damn neared died in the process.  My second and third Onc followed me with TM's and CT scans - with the CT scans they are looking as much for symptoms as tumors.  By that I mean they are checking for fluid in the abdomen (ascites) or fluid in the lung - the bodies reaction to the cancer rather than the cancer itself. Not only are these scans inadequate for many lobular patients (but not all lobular patients), what you have to really watch is that lobular can Met to very odd places like those I mentioned above - like microscopic critters that gum up the works in my lungs and bone marrow. What is critical for a lobular patient is to see an Onc that see's a lot of lobular (17% of BC patients).  If you are seeing a general Onc, many or most of these do not see enough lobular cancer.  I am currently seeing a Breast Onc at a University. I also wanted to add that I'm not sure that this is because the cells are less dense (I'll ask my Onc about this) but that lobular is kind of stringy - it very often does not form tumors, as such.  It strings itself out.  When the surgeon completed my surgery, she said that I had lobular cancer growing from the breast down into the nodes - very stringy.  In order for something to show up on a PET, I believe it has to be around half the size of a pea.
Posts.Title: Are ILC Mets Harder to Detect on PET? sdisilvestri dianaleo
